channel.title: Enron collapse?
channel.description:
http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/americas/5182068.stm
Well, do you think these men are responsible for the collapse of Enron? I'm undecided, but I don't think their sentence was justified. Maybe a hefty fine? =\
post your views.
If you don't know what Enron was, Google it.
EDIT: - Hmm, interesting, seems no-one here is interested in this kind of stuff.. :cool:

item.title: Enron collapse?
item.dc:creator: @philodespotos philodespotos
item.description:
@philodespotos wrote:

Umm. Enron employed thousands. Why would you assume that they were “pretty well off to begin with”? As if they don’t have mail room clerks, or secretaries, or janitors, or any other bottom-of-the-middle-class employees there? Innumerable people lost all of their retirement savings – they will be working well into their eighties. People who had worked for the company since its inception are now bordering on homeless. This is a very well documented case of pervasive corporate corruption. It’s not up for debate: they defrauded entire states of amounts of money that you and I can’t even begin to comprehened.

There’s nothing left to consider here. White collar crime should be held to the same standard as any other type. When you ruin the lives of thousands, you must be held accountable, and rigidly so.

The only regrettable factor is that Lay died when he did, as it puts the civil suits in jeopardy, and effectively negates his conviction, since he had not yet been sentenced.

Read full topic

daycrawler:
